author: samuraiturtle
title: It Is Time For The Show
review: The cheapest way to get the "Jester" figure.  Their is not much to say about this set.  It comes with a stage to perform on and some studs to juggle with.  The jester does have a sad expression along with his happy one.  The main reason to get this set is for the "Jester".

author: Freezdried
title: The jester must be breaking wind...
review:
Apparently flags can move in whatever direction they want to in Legoland, because the two flags on top of the stage in this set go in opposite directions.  Other than that annoying design flaw, this set is actually pretty nice.  It definitely looks like a medieval stage, like something you'd see at a renaissance fair.  And unlike the 'props' you find in other impulse sets, this one actually serves a purpose.  I'm sure I'll find a place for it somewhere.

Let's face it: you aren't going to buy this set for the flags, or the stage - you want the jester.  And he's a pretty solid figure.  He's got the reversible head with a super-happy face on one side, and a super-sad face on the other.  The torso is printed on front and back, with nice detailing (including a lion belt buckle that shows his alliance with the lion knights!)  Plus, the LEGO design team once again shows us how innovative they can be with existing parts by using round 1x1 plates for juggling balls.  Nice touch.

As for the building experience, it's easy and not much to talk about.  But that's about what you should expect for an impulse set like this.  My four-year-old built it on his own without any help, so it's a breeze.

Overall, I think this is a worthy set to get, but not something you should go out of your way to find.  And if you find it on sale, you'd be a 'fool' not to get it!

author: MetroiD
title: Finally, the jester goes cheap
review:
Who cares about flags - it's the jester, and he's finally up for grabs! All by himself, this time performing solo, without any of those boring merry-go-rounds, castles or towers.

Well, 'boring' might not be the best word here, but really, LEGO couldn't have introduced a better impulse set. The jester is probably one of the most desirable Castle minifigures and now there's finally a way to own him in sufficient quantities to create your own jester-filled circus, without splashing out on a huge set (or tons of them).

So the flags point in different directions and the build is fragile, so what? It is, at the end of the day, an impulse set and I highly doubt that there'd be too many of you who'd keep the jester's scene as shown. Slopes and brown pieces are always welcome in my parts bin, so I definitely don't have any complaints whatsoever regarding the parts, or the value for money.

Fair enough, you'd have to be good at juggling yourself if you want this set to even come close to being exciting, but put the jester in proper surroundings and you'll most definitely be in for a treat!

author: rr253
title: Not The Best
review:
This set is not the best. The minifig is great though.

  • pros: Great minifig
  •        cool stage.
  • cons: falls apart

       Other than that I would rate this a 4/5.

author: myater
title: Easy Jester
review:
Stopped by the TRU today and picked up this on at my wife's request.  Afterwards I was glad that we did pick it up.  Kinda curious about dual directions flags, but what kind of performer wants to follow the laws of nature anyway!

 

Pros: great individual stage, much like what you can see at a Renaissance Fair for small performances, Juggling balls inginuity (1x1 rounds), and the Jester!

 

Cons: $4.50 for the set, and only 21 pieces plus the minifig.  But that seems to be the economy more than anything.

 

Overall:  Get it and get the Jester

author: con00
title: too easy
review:
the strange thing is, is that when i first saw this set i knew how to build it. same with all the ben10 sets and the new wizard set.

i'm so strange

pros: simple, pricing is OK, and a jester cap has never come in such a cheap set

cons: its fun for like two mins, unstable

author: debarg
title: must have addition to any castle
review: Nice little set that can't be missed in any castle theme. The joyful character of the jester reminds me of Danny Kaye. The illusion of this minifig really juggling is great. The red-gold flags are easily replaced in your favorite castle colors.

author: legomaniac101
title: cute little set
review: I got this set at a super market with city set 7566 farmer,this set may be small,but it is very cute... there isn't much playablitey to it,so if you like sets with lots of playablity,this isn't for you.

author: legospongepotter
title: If you see it, buy it!
review:
I saw it at Walmart and decided to just get it. It's not much. The build is so easy, you don't need the instructions. There is a small platform with some colorful decoration thing in the back. 
The minifugre is the reason I bought this. It has a great hat like a normal jester and it has a double-sided face. One happy, one crying. The suit is basically red and white design. That's really it. So if you see this set, buy it.

author: bogdanst
title: Jester is great
review:
First of all this is an impulse set. That being said, this is a great impuls set! A jester was a rare minifig, first came in advent calendar (which was a seasonal set, so after christmas, it was mostly unavailable), than came in a big set (which was perhaps out of reach for those that didn't want to spend a lot of money to get yet another tower, with more knights, just for one minifig - ok, the lady in distress in that set was also a nice touch, and maybe would make that purchase a worthwhile). Now everyone can have their own jester, because you will buy this set for the minifig and nothing else, or you won't buy it at all.


And a word or two about the stage - the stability is not that bad, round bricks go into the plate, on the plate you have those slopes, and on the slope you have a 1x6 plate - there is nothing unstable about that. The flags are not representing flags in that set, well not flags that wave on the wind, anyway. They are a stage decoration, or maybe a stage curtain, so them facing opposite direction is not a violation of physics. Just a small imaginative detail for the impulse set (and impulses always have parts that are pretending to be something else, because they have a limited number of parts that are put into these sets).


Jester is a must-have minifig, so the price is not that high (consider the rarity of a jester, and then compare it to the common wizard that comes in the second impulse set, at the same price). The stage is nicely designed for an impulse set, well not very hard to build - but still. The printing on the jester is great (only, my headpiece has a slight color smudge, but nothing noticeable). And the playability is just individual ;)

But I highly recommend this set to everyone, since you can't go wrong with a jester.

author: welz
title: Good, if your into a castle setup!
review: I found this set great for my castle set up! if you dont have a setup then this guy may be a bit pricy but i found it worth while since he's my first jester! so if you love castle sets a definent buy:D

author: AETerry
title: Court Jester Review
review:
This is or was the cheapest set and way to get a Jester Minifigure for Castle. I can see placing this set in a medieval type fair where he's entertaining a crowd. How else to explain the stage that he's standing on?

Instructions

The instructions are printed on a folded sheet of paper, either side with LEGO's clear step-by-step illustrations.

Parts

There's only 22 pieces in this set, most of which are red and white to complement the colors of the Jester's outfit.

Minifigures

The Court Jester is the main draw and feature of this set and I must say he is well worth it. Unlike Harley Quinn who is red and black or another Jester in the Fantasy Era theme that's blue and red, this particular Jester is red and white, complimenting him well with the colors for the Kingdoms theme.

Its for this minifigure alone, that makes buying this small set worth it.

The build and completed model

As a small set, there's really not much of a build. You've got just enough pieces to make an alternating red & white stage that the Jester stands on while he's juggling his round 1x1 plates or balls.

Summary

Where so many Castle sets feature Castles, Towers, War Wagons and Vehicles and army building minifigures, the Court Jester adds a flair of character and whimsy, reminding people that Castle wasn't all about sieges and wars, there are other aspects to the Castle theme. At $5 picking this up from Brickcon, this set was well worth it to me. If you love Jesters, this set is a must to get. So many possibilities with him outside of keeping him just straight Castle too for play and MOC building.

author: clundsberg
title: Doin' It All For The Jester
review:
I bought this set today as a gift to get my son the Jester figure and becasue the store did not have any of those single pack secret figures.  Let's face it, the figure is the main draw for this set.  Legoland exemplified this in their 3-D movie so I'm very glad they made an affordable set in which to obtain this figure.

The simple stage he juggles upon is a nice touch.  It makes sense in context and can be added to any castle set nicely.  It bothers me not that it's a pretty basic set as again I think most people that buy this set are doing so for the figure.

If you have $5 on you and want a nice treat for yor child or want to add to your sets on a budget this is for you.

The unique figure is a the main plus of this set, unless you have a child in which case their expression at receiving this is the true reward. :)

Thank you, Lego for making a rare figure easily accessible. (now where's that Admiral Ackbar?)

author: Odeinoichus
title: Did you Hear the One about the King and his Horse?
review:
Set #7953 Court Jester: Another Impulse set that is one of the better ones. I finally picked this up today after months of waiting and biding my time and I was not dissapointed. This set is well worth the money, it gives you a small stage to put your Jester on and of course the much coveted Court Jester Mini-Figure, a rare figure indeed.

 

It's a cheap little alternative to paying for the larger sets if you're only interested in the Court Jester. As a bonus he comes with a double-sided torso and head, and the unique looking cap is a nice accessory. You get two of each colored stud to use as juggling balls, and some jugglers can juggle all six of them, sadly not the LEGO Jester. (At least not without a bit of support from you the player.) I highly recommend this set to anyone who enjoys the Castle theme.

author: alva
title: A Simple Impulse with a Great Impact
review:
As you know, people on middle age (during the castle era) does not have many entertainment. They do not have TV, radio, internet, etc. So, the choice of entertainment was very limited at that time. One of entertainment that available at that time is clown/jester. So, really happy that Lego launched this impulse. It really make the castle theme more alive and more real. You can put him and the stand anywhere in your castle and put some minifigs to watch him. Really nice.
In term of design, I love how Lego create the set with half red half white color. I think it is really complement each other, and also matching with Lion Knights color.

If you have some castle/kingdom sets, you should have this set, at least one, and it will make your middle age city more fun.

author: youngtom
title: "Now time for me to juggle...1 ball... 2 ball... 3 ball...oops!" - The Jester
review:
I got this set yesterday and it's really cool.

Minifigures:
Just a really cool jester.
He has a really cool jester's hat that comes in a little bag when you get it.
He also comes w/ a really cool double-sided head, it's happy and sad.
Also a cool jester's uniform (Torso and pants).

The Jester's Stage:
This part is really fragile.
It has cool flag pieces.
It's a really cool stand.
It comes w/ 3 juggling balls w/ the colors, red, white & blue.

Extra Parts:
The same 3 juggling balls w/ the colors red,white & blue.


If you see it GET IT.
Cool for any Castle/Kingdoms or City.

author: Berrus_Brickus
title: Moodswing
review:
Let's get right to the swingin':

Box/Instructions

Simple, the boxart is just the Jester standing on the podium while juggling three studs.  The instructions are a little flyer which really streches out building the podium.

 

Parts

Very basic parts, nothing really to discuss, which is standard for most impulses (not until the minifigures section at least).  It does come with some extra "balls" though, nice to have some extras.  The only real problem I have with the simple structure is the color scheme.  Though it is my first golden flag, a white on would have matched the red/white coloring better.

 

Minifigures

Here we go, the reason to get this set, the Jester.  The legs are simple non-printed minifig legs except one leg is colored red to fit the colors of the lion knights.  The torso is the same as the Fantasy Era jester's except instead of blue printing, it has white.  The face is probably my favorite part of figure.  It is a double face, one side with an annoyingly large smile, the other with an expression of the jester crying, which really reminds me of the Comedy and Tragedy masks from ancient Greece.  And if you would like to know, the face is what inspiered me to call this review Moodswing.  The hat is the one thing that bugs me and I am sorry to waste your time with this, but it messes up the pattern.  (From the right side of the 'fig feet to hat, we have white, red, white, white [, and the little red ball].  This problem did not exist on his Fantasy Era counter part.)

 

The build

Nothing really worth while.  It'll take longer to read this review then to build it.

 

The completed model

Not much, just a little stand, which despite it's occupation, is a horrible stand alone set.  Though I admit that as of today (1/14/11) it is my only Kingdoms set besides the wizard.  It would go nicely with Medievel Market Village or the 2010 castle.  I actually use it in my city as a street performing stand.

 

Summary

To summarise this, I will close my review.  Simply only get it for the minifig, though his pattern is messed up, the white/red color scheme is much better than the blue/red one. But keep in mind that it is just an impulse set and not really worth being tracked down now that it has been discontinued.

author: Ernst
title: The king wants to smile, you will definitly!!
review:
Overall 5 bricks: why 5 stars for 22 pieces? Because the court finally has his Jester, he looks great and he is priced brilliant !!

 

Building experience 2 bricks: putting 22 parts together is not what you can call building.

 

Parts 4 bricks: nice minifigure with the right colors and accesoires and a cool stage. Love the double face and the cool hat.

 

Playability 3 bricks: if he could really juggle it would have been 5.

 

Value 5 bricks: hey, it costs only €4,00 !! Need I say more ? Buy it and place it in your Castle.

author: Graysmith
title: A Collectable Minifigure In Its Own Right
review:
Though this jester wasn't released as part of the Collectable Minifigures theme, it could just as well have been because it's just as good as any of those figures (and better than many of them). He's got a beautiful torso with printing on both sides, a double-faced happy/sad head and a really great hat.

It'll set you back a little bit more than the Collectable Minifigures, but you get a very nice little stage to go with him that makes those small black stands you get with the Collectables pale by comparison. It's not much as far as parts go, but it perfectly evokes the idea of a travelling entertainer with a stage he could set up in any town he visited. I think it looks just lovely for being such a simple build.

The only negative comment I have is that I would've liked to have seen the hands follow the red/white alternating colour scheme of the rest of him. I put a red hand on the white arm and a white hand on the red arm and I personally think that makes him look even better. Still a gorgeous minifigure though, and a very easy modification to make if you have the hands to spare.

Bottom line: A fun little guy well worth getting even if you're not into the Castle/Kingdoms theme.

author: wii1232
title: A Small Set
review:
When I looked at the box, it looked pretty small.  And that made sense as soon as a looked at the building instructions.  They were a folded sheet of paper rather than multiple pages.

Once I looked at the Jester's face, I realized it was double-sided, with a happy face on one side, and a sad, crying face on the other.  As soon as I put him on the stage with is balls to juggle with, I knew that the stage would've had to be much bigger for it to make sense.  It looked as if it was either a tiny stage, or there was a big Jester standing on it.

author: Lego_fan_
title: The jester
review:
Lego set #7952 is a great addition to any Lego castle collection.

This set is a perfect addition to you castle court yard to entertain the castle guards. 

This set includes one Jester minifigure and a stage.

The Jester himself is the same Jester torso as seen before but his head is double sided one happy and one crying face. 

The stage is about two inches tall and is a very fast build.

Overall i think this set is a fun little addition to any castle collection and is great for filling in your castle court yard.
